text: a short boat trip across the river
tigris takes you from Iraq into northern
Syria
the Kurds have forged their own path
through the brutal civil war between the
opposition and the regime
[Music]
as they've carved out their territory so
of the Islamic state this is their
frontline is fighters are holed up just
a few kilometers away around the third
of the Syrian Kurdish fighting force is
made up of women many of them are still
teenagers they fight alongside the men
facing the same enemy and the same
dangers years old when they see a woman
with a gun they're so afraid they begin
to shake they portray themselves as
tough guys to the world they see women
as just little things but one of our
women is worth a hundred of them
the Kurds have been battling the Islamic
state for more than two years now
unlike the Iraqis they've managed to
defend their territory without the help
of US airstrikes they've also taken
prisoners some of them were marched in
front of our camera we weren't allowed
to speak to them but their jailers said
they were Syrian Arabs caught fighting
alongside the is most of the ones we
catch are locals the foreign fighters
always suicide belts and when we
captured him they blow themselves up in
the deserted villages around the
frontline one of the few signs of life
is the barrel of a tank peeping out from
behind a mud hunt well the Kurds have
got their flag flying from atop that
little hillock there the Islamic state
are in control of the next village that
one shimmering in the distance over
there and the only people that are left
they're here to fight the war has split
communities here some Sunni Arab
villages support the Islamic state but
others have joined the Kurds half of the
people around here are with is they
opened their gates to them they were our
neighbors our families until they joined
Islamic state it is this local support
that has allowed the is to spread like a
cancer through the region and the Kurds
know they can't defeat them on their own
Gabriel gatehouse BBC news in northern
Syria
